attributes.title: Psychological implications and government response in times of COVID-19
attributes.description: This is a preregistration project for the analysis of the COVIDiSTRESS global survey data jointly with the Oxford COVID-19 Government Response Tracker data

q1.value: Dominik-Borna Ćepulić, Ivan Flis, Marta Kowal

q2.value:
Hypotheses are non-directional.

H1: The Oxford Government Response Stringency Index is related to the perceived stress levels.
H2: The Oxford Government Response Stringency Index is related to the trust towards the national institutions.
H3: The Oxford Government Response Stringency Index is related to compliance levels with the health recommendations.
H4: The Oxford Government Response Stringency Index is related to the perceived stringency of national health measures.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
According to the pre-registration of COVIDiSTRESS global survey (which can be found under the link: https://osf.io/s32gy):

The COVIDiSTRESS global survey is an international collaborative undertaking for data gathering on people’s experiences, behavior and attitudes during the COVID-19 pandemic. In particular, the survey focuses on psychological stress, compliance with behavioral guidelines to slow the spread of Coronavirus, and trust in governmental institutions and their preventive measures, but multiple further items and scales are included for descriptive statistics, further analysis and comparative mapping between participating countries.

To gather comparable data swiftly from across the globe, the collaboration and survey was constructed as an urgent collaborative process in late March 2020.

q8.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

q9.value:
The data collection has began on March 30, 2020.
Data will be made available for public use on the Open Science Framework. Data extraction is scheduled for cumulative “dumps” every Monday until May 30, 2020.
The first data extraction will take place in afternoon of April 06, 2020, and the current pre-registration is being submitted before the first data extraction. 

The Oxford Government Response Strigency Index data have been made publicly available online before the first COVIDiSTRESS Global Survey data extraction. The data have been analyzed by the OxCGRT team. We did not preform any analyses on the Oxford Government Response Strigency Index data before the registration.

question.value: Data is being collected by committed researchers in 43+ countries. Data is collected online, mainly based on social snowballing, viral spread and help from interested partners.

q11.value: We intend to analyze the data from countries, where minimum of 300 responses have been collected.

question.value:
The Oxford Government Response Stringency Index - this is a baseline measure of variation in governments’ responses to the COVID-19. It is a composite measure calculated as a simple additive score of the seven indicators (S1-S7) measured on an ordinal scale, rescaled to vary from 0 to 100 (for details see https://www.bsg.ox.ac.uk/research/research-projects/oxford-covid-19-government-response-tracker)

Perceived stress level - This variable will be assessed by the Perceived Stress Scale, 10-item version (Cohen et al., 1983) and their respective language adaptations (if available), or forward-back translations, using WHO recommendations.  

Trust towards institutions - indicated by the 6 OECD questions measuring trust in country's government and health system (on a scale from 0-10 (0=not at all, 10=completely), how much you personally trust each of the institutions: (1) parliament/government?, (2) police, (3) civil service, (4) health system (added; not in the original version), (5) WHO (added; not in the original version), (6) government’s effort to handle Coronavirus (added; not in the original version). For more details, see https://www.oecd.org/governance/oecd-guidelines-on-measuring-trust-9789264278219-en.htm

Compliance levels - measured by 6 own self-reported items to capture compliance with local prevention guidelines on a 6-Point Likert Scale (1=strongly disagree, 6=strongly agree). Mean score will be computed.

Perceived stringency of national health measures - measured by the question "All things considered, do you believe that [Country’s] government has taken the appropriate measures in response to Coronavirus?" Scale: 0=too little, 5= appropriate, 10=too much

We will conduct a multilevel linear regression analyses to test whether the predictor (The Oxford Government Response Stringency Index) is related to each of dependent variables (perceived stress levels, trust towards the national institutions, compliance levels with the health recommendations, the perceived stringency of national health measures) across countries which have more than 300 complete responses.

attributes.title: Advanced analytical methods to assess physical activity behaviour using accelerometer time series raw data: A protocol for a scoping review
attributes.description: This is a scoping review protocol to map advanced analytical approaches and their multidimensional summary variables used to provide a comprehensive picture of PA behaviour of an individual. Therefore, this scoping review will look at analytical methods that go beyond total PA volume, average daily acceleration and the conventional cut-point approaches, involving tri-axial accelerometer data from any sensor attachment location, and covering both data- and knowledge driven techniques.

summary.value:
Physical activity (PA) is a complex multidimensional human behaviour. Currently, there is no standardized approach for measuring PA using wearable accelerometers in health research. The total volume of PA accumulated over time is an important variable because it includes the frequency, intensity, and duration of activity bouts, but it reduces them down to a single summary variable, which comes with loss of information. Therefore, analytical approaches using accelerometer time series raw data taking into account the way PA is accumulated over time may provide more clinically relevant features of physical behaviour. The objective of this review will be to map advanced analytical approaches and their multidimensional summary variables used to provide a comprehensive picture of PA behaviour.
This scoping review will be guided by the Arksey and O'Malley methodological framework and the Joanna Briggs Institute methods manual. A search for relevant publications will be undertaken in Medline/ Pubmed, Embase and Web of Science databases. The selection of articles will be limited to studies published in English from January 2010 to April 2020. Studies including analytical methods that go beyond total PA volume, average daily acceleration and the conventional cut-point approaches, involving tri-axial accelerometer data will be included. All references will be exported to Endnote library. Two reviewers will independently screen all citations, full-text articles, and extract data. The data will be collated, stored, and charted to provide a descriptive summary of the analytical methods and outputs, their strengths and limitations, as well as their association with different health outcomes.
This protocol describes a systematic method to identify, map, and synthesize advanced analytical approaches and their multidimensional summary variables used to investigate PA behaviour and identify potentially clinically relevant features. The results of this review will be useful to guide future research related to analysing PA patterns, investigate their association with health conditions, and suggest appropriate recommendations for changes in PA behaviour. The results may be of interest to sports scientist, clinical researchers, and smartphone application developers in the field of PA assessment.

attributes.title: The Withdrawal Assessment Tool (WAT-1) to identify iatrogenic withdrawal symptoms in critically ill pediatric patients: a COSMIN systematic review of measurement properties.

summary.value:
Background

Sedatives (most commonly opioids and benzodiazepines,) are necessary to treat pain, agitation and to tolerate invasive procedures such as mechanical ventilation. (1-4) Indeed, current practices indicate that nearly all mechanically ventilated patients in pediatric intensive care units (PICU) receive sedatives during the critical phase of their PICU stay. (5) However, extended exposure to sedatives often results in delays in weaning from mechanical ventilation, extends the length of PICU stay, and increases the risk of delirium. (6, 7) For this reason, guidelines concerning the use of sedatives strongly favor light levels of use, designed to improve patient outcomes in the PICU (e.g. length-of-stay) and post-PICU (e.g. neurocognition and physical functioning). (3, 8, 9) 
In the adult population, extended sedative exposure is reduced by using daily sedation interruption methods to minimize sedative use and improve outcomes. (1, 10) Daily sedative interruptions are defined as a period of time, each day, during which the patient’s medication is discontinued to allow patients to wake up and achieve arousal. (8) Unfortunately, the effectiveness and safety of daily sedative interruptions in the pediatric population have not been established. Results from the few existing studies in the pediatric population indicate that the use of adult guidelines may not be appropriate. (6, 11-13) Consequently, the current best practice in children is to gradually discontinue sedative medications as they move towards the recovery phase of their illness. Unfortunately, if sedatives are abruptly stopped or weaned too quickly, iatrogenic withdrawal syndrome (IWS) occurs. (14) 
IWS can result in prolonged and adverse health outcomes for patients. The symptoms include central nervous system hyperirritability, autonomic system dysregulation, gastrointestinal dysfunction, and motor abnormalities. (15-17) IWS typically appears in individuals who receive regular sedatives for more than 72 hours. IWS can appear in patients who: 1) are weaned from ≥ 5 days of continuous infusion or round-the-clock sedatives and 2) are receiving rescue therapy to manage an increase in symptoms after the start of weaning, and not for treatment of new pain or sedation needs. (18) The incidence of IWS is most common in critically ill pediatric populations, in part due to the differences in sedative methods between adult and pediatric populations. Specifically, the incidence of IWS in critically ill pediatric patients is estimated to range from 7.5%- 87%. (19) 
Currently, a gold standard for diagnosing pediatric IWS doesn’t exist, despite the high incidence rate of IWS in the PICU. Instead, health care professionals are required to apply subjective clinical assessments to qualify a patient’s withdrawal intensity and symptoms. (20) This subjective assessment leads to missed diagnoses and variable management, which may contribute to more adverse outcomes. To address these issues, there is a need for a validated measurement tool to allow for earlier diagnoses, standardize IWS assessment, evaluate treatment effectiveness, and guide clinical practice.
The Withdrawal Assessment Tool (WAT-1) is a clinician-reported outcome measure developed to measure IWS in critically ill children. The WAT-1 can be used to diagnose IWS in pediatric populations and assess the clinical effectiveness of treatments. (2, 3, 21) While existing studies have validated specific measurement properties of the WAT-1 (20), to our knowledge, no studies aggregate its measurement properties. Aggregating the psychometric research on the WAT-1 will enhance our understanding of the appropriate use of the WAT-1, and outline areas of weaknesses that require future empirical research. Thus, the aim of this systematic review is to critically appraise, compare and summarize the psychometric properties, the interpretability, the feasibility and the evidence quality of the WAT-1 for identifying IWS symptoms in critically ill children. 

Methods
We will conduct a systematic review of the WAT-1 in pediatric populations according to the COnsensus-based Standards for the selection of health Measurement Instruments (COSMIN) guidelines. The COSMIN guidelines provide rigorous methodology and standards that assess measurement properties, feasibility and interpretability of an instrument, and the methodological quality of the studies which report measurement properties. (22-25) This study will be reported according to both PRISMA and COSMIN guidelines. (23, 24, 26)
 
Eligibility
Peer-reviewed, full-text articles on WAT-1 development, evaluation of one or more measurement properties (e.g. reliability, validity, and responsiveness), or its interpretation and feasibility are eligible for inclusion. Studies that use the WAT-1 as a measure of outcomes only, or to validate another measure will be excluded. Any studies that use the WAT-1 in adult populations (>18 years of age) will be excluded. In alignment with specific COSMIN recommendations, posters and abstracts will be excluded because they do not have enough information about the study design. Only articles available in English or French will be included.

Search strategy
Literature sources
The following electronic databases will be searched from inception to the date of submitting this protocol: Medline, Embase, and CINHAL. Once the included articles from electronic databases are identified, their reference lists will be screened for additional pertinent records. Finally, the original creator of the WAT-1 will be consulted for pertinent literature that may have been missed. 

Search strategy
The search strategy was developed by the lead author (MZ) and reviewed by the research team (RA, MN) and a medical librarian. The search strategy used COSMIN’s comprehensive methodological search filter for PubMed, with 97.4% sensitivity and 9.4% specificity in identifying studies on measurement properties. (27) This validated filter has been translated for Embase (28) and CINAHL. (29) No limits were applied to the publication type, date, age, or methodology. Each database search strategy appears in Appendix 1.

Data management
Following the search, all identified records will be saved and uploaded into EndNote X9.1 (Clarivate Analytics, PA, USA) and duplicates removed. The papers will then be uploaded to the freely accessible web tool Rayyan QCRI. (30) Rayyan is a free web-tool designed to facilitate the screening of articles for systematic reviews.  

Selection of studies
Two reviewers will independently screen the full sample of records. First, titles and abstracts of each record will be appraised against the eligibility criteria. Any article deemed relevant by either reviewer will be considered for full-text extraction. Following the abstract screening, full texts of the included articles will be retrieved and evaluated for eligibility. Any disagreement about eligibility at the full-text review stage will be resolved through discussion, or with a third investigator until a full consensus is obtained.

Data Extraction
Two independent reviewers will extract data using a predefined online data collection sheet provided by COSMIN and mounted on Microsoft Excel. (31) The reviewers will extract general characteristics of the instrument (e.g. mode of administration), the characteristics of the study sample (e.g. demographics, age, gender, disease), the results regarding the measurement properties and the feasibility and interpretability of the WAT-1. 
Assessment of included studies methodological quality
The COSMIN four-point risk-of-bias checklist will be used to assess the methodological quality of the included studies. (22) The COSMIN four-point checklists contain several questions/standards concerning the design requirements and the necessary statistical methods for each measurement property to be evaluated. Each question or standard is scored as very good, adequate, doubtful, inadequate or not applicable (N/A). The overall score per measurement property per study is determined by taking the lowest rating of any question or standard for each measurement property (i.e. worst-score-counts).

Assessment of measurement properties
Measurement properties are defined according to the COSMIN taxonomy. (24) Appendix 2 defines each measurement property. Evidence of good measurement properties will be based on COSMIN’s (32) modified criteria for good measurement properties as adapted from Terwee et al (Appendix 3). (33) Measurement properties will be labeled as sufficient (+), insufficient (–) or indeterminate (?). Interpretability and feasibility will be assessed qualitatively as they are not strictly a measurement property; however, they are important in assessing the utility of measures. 

Summarizing measurement properties results
The measurement property labels across studies will be qualitatively summarized into one overall category. If the results are inconsistent, the authors will subdivide included studies (e.g. based on population subgroup) to allow for qualitative summary. If this is not possible, then a summarized label of inconsistent will be given. Thus, the overall rating for the summarized results can be sufficient (+), insufficient (–), inconsistent (±), or indeterminate (?). (Appendix 3) 

Grading the quality of evidence 
After summarizing and rating all evidence for each measurement property, the final step is to grade the quality of the evidence. The quality of the evidence refers to the confidence that the pooled or summarized result is trustworthy. The grading of the quality will be based on the Grading of Recommendations Assessment, Development, and Evaluation (GRADE) approach for systematic reviews of clinical trials. (34) This approach grades the quality of the evidence as high, moderate, low, or very low. (35)

Discussion
This systematic review aims to assess the psychometric properties, feasibility, interpretability and quality evidence of the WAT-1 tool. This tool measures IWS symptoms caused by opioid and benzodiazepine withdrawal symptoms in critically ill pediatric patients, to establish an early diagnosis and evaluate subsequent treatment effectiveness. Conducting a systematic review of measurement properties may further support the WAT-1’s inclusion as a psychometrically robust tool for daily clinical use. Additionally, it may encourage increased use of the WAT-1, leading to an increased understanding and identification of IWS in pediatric populations, leading to more effective clinical treatments and, ultimately, improved patient outcomes.

Ethics
No ethical approval is required. This research uses already published literature. 

Conflicts of Interest
All authors report no conflicts of interest.

Acknowledgments
We would like to thank Lydia Thorpe, the medical librarian from Ontario Tech University for peer-reviewing our search strategy.

Unfortunately, if sedatives are abruptly stopped or weaned too quickly, iatrogenic withdrawal syndrome (IWS) occurs. (14) 
IWS can result in prolonged and adverse health outcomes for patients. The symptoms include central nervous system hyperirritability, autonomic system dysregulation, gastrointestinal dysfunction, and motor abnormalities. (15-17) IWS typically appears in individuals who receive regular sedatives for more than 72 hours. IWS can appear in patients who: 1) are weaned from ≥ 5 days of continuous infusion or round-the-clock sedatives and 2) are receiving rescue therapy to manage an increase in symptoms after the start of weaning, and not for treatment of new pain or sedation needs. (18) The incidence of IWS is most common in critically ill pediatric populations, in part due to the differences in sedative methods between adult and pediatric populations. Specifically, the incidence of IWS in critically ill pediatric patients is estimated to range from 7.5%- 87%. (19) 
Currently, a gold standard for diagnosing pediatric IWS doesn’t exist, despite the high incidence rate of IWS in the PICU. Instead, health care professionals are required to apply subjective clinical assessments to qualify a patient’s withdrawal intensity and symptoms. (20) This subjective assessment leads to missed diagnoses and variable management, which may contribute to more adverse outcomes. To address these issues, there is a need for a validated measurement tool to allow for earlier diagnoses, standardize IWS assessment, evaluate treatment effectiveness, and guide clinical practice.
The Withdrawal Assessment Tool (WAT-1) is a clinician-reported outcome measure developed to measure IWS in critically ill children. The WAT-1 can be used to diagnose IWS in pediatric populations and assess the clinical effectiveness of treatments. (2, 3, 21) While existing studies have validated specific measurement properties of the WAT-1 (20), to our knowledge, no studies aggregate its measurement properties. Aggregating the psychometric research on the WAT-1 will enhance our understanding of the appropriate use of the WAT-1, and outline areas of weaknesses that require future empirical research. Thus, the aim of this systematic review is to critically appraise, compare and summarize the psychometric properties, the interpretability, the feasibility and the evidence quality of the WAT-1 for identifying IWS symptoms in critically ill children. 

Methods
We will conduct a systematic review of the WAT-1 in pediatric populations according to the COnsensus-based Standards for the selection of health Measurement Instruments (COSMIN) guidelines. The COSMIN guidelines provide rigorous methodology and standards that assess measurement properties, feasibility and interpretability of an instrument, and the methodological quality of the studies which report measurement properties. (22-25) This study will be reported according to both PRISMA and COSMIN guidelines. (23, 24, 26)
 
Eligibility
Peer-reviewed, full-text articles on WAT-1 development, evaluation of one or more measurement properties (e.g. reliability, validity, and responsiveness), or its interpretation and feasibility are eligible for inclusion. Studies that use the WAT-1 as a measure of outcomes only, or to validate another measure will be excluded. Any studies that use the WAT-1 in adult populations (>18 years of age) will be excluded. In alignment with specific COSMIN recommendations, posters and abstracts will be excluded because they do not have enough information about the study design. Only articles available in English or French will be included.

Search strategy
Literature sources
The following electronic databases will be searched from inception to the date of submitting this protocol: Medline, Embase, and CINHAL. Once the included articles from electronic databases are identified, their reference lists will be screened for additional pertinent records. Finally, the original creator of the WAT-1 will be consulted for pertinent literature that may have been missed. 

Search strategy
The search strategy was developed by the lead author (MZ) and reviewed by the research team (RA, MN) and a medical librarian. The search strategy used COSMIN’s comprehensive methodological search filter for PubMed, with 97.4% sensitivity and 9.4% specificity in identifying studies on measurement properties. (27) This validated filter has been translated for Embase (28) and CINAHL. (29) No limits were applied to the publication type, date, age, or methodology. Each database search strategy appears in Appendix 1.

Data management
Following the search, all identified records will be saved and uploaded into EndNote X9.1 (Clarivate Analytics, PA, USA) and duplicates removed. The papers will then be uploaded to the freely accessible web tool Rayyan QCRI. (30) Rayyan is a free web-tool designed to facilitate the screening of articles for systematic reviews.  

Selection of studies
Two reviewers will independently screen the full sample of records. First, titles and abstracts of each record will be appraised against the eligibility criteria. Any article deemed relevant by either reviewer will be considered for full-text extraction. Following the abstract screening, full texts of the included articles will be retrieved and evaluated for eligibility. Any disagreement about eligibility at the full-text review stage will be resolved through discussion, or with a third investigator until a full consensus is obtained.

Data Extraction
Two independent reviewers will extract data using a predefined online data collection sheet provided by COSMIN and mounted on Microsoft Excel. (31) The reviewers will extract general characteristics of the instrument (e.g. mode of administration), the characteristics of the study sample (e.g. demographics, age, gender, disease), the results regarding the measurement properties and the feasibility and interpretability of the WAT-1. 
Assessment of included studies methodological quality
The COSMIN four-point risk-of-bias checklist will be used to assess the methodological quality of the included studies. (22) The COSMIN four-point checklists contain several questions/standards concerning the design requirements and the necessary statistical methods for each measurement property to be evaluated. Each question or standard is scored as very good, adequate, doubtful, inadequate or not applicable (N/A). The overall score per measurement property per study is determined by taking the lowest rating of any question or standard for each measurement property (i.e. worst-score-counts).

Assessment of measurement properties
Measurement properties are defined according to the COSMIN taxonomy. (24) Appendix 2 defines each measurement property. Evidence of good measurement properties will be based on COSMIN’s (32) modified criteria for good measurement properties as adapted from Terwee et al (Appendix 3). (33) Measurement properties will be labeled as sufficient (+), insufficient (–) or indeterminate (?). Interpretability and feasibility will be assessed qualitatively as they are not strictly a measurement property; however, they are important in assessing the utility of measures. 

Summarizing measurement properties results
The measurement property labels across studies will be qualitatively summarized into one overall category. If the results are inconsistent, the authors will subdivide included studies (e.g. based on population subgroup) to allow for qualitative summary. If this is not possible, then a summarized label of inconsistent will be given. Thus, the overall rating for the summarized results can be sufficient (+), insufficient (–), inconsistent (±), or indeterminate (?). (Appendix 3) 

Grading the quality of evidence 
After summarizing and rating all evidence for each measurement property, the final step is to grade the quality of the evidence. The quality of the evidence refers to the confidence that the pooled or summarized result is trustworthy. The grading of the quality will be based on the Grading of Recommendations Assessment, Development, and Evaluation (GRADE) approach for systematic reviews of clinical trials. (34) This approach grades the quality of the evidence as high, moderate, low, or very low. (35)

Discussion
This systematic review aims to assess the psychometric properties, feasibility, interpretability and quality evidence of the WAT-1 tool. This tool measures IWS symptoms caused by opioid and benzodiazepine withdrawal symptoms in critically ill pediatric patients, to establish an early diagnosis and evaluate subsequent treatment effectiveness. Conducting a systematic review of measurement properties may further support the WAT-1’s inclusion as a psychometrically robust tool for daily clinical use. Additionally, it may encourage increased use of the WAT-1, leading to an increased understanding and identification of IWS in pediatric populations, leading to more effective clinical treatments and, ultimately, improved patient outcomes.

Ethics
No ethical approval is required. This research uses already published literature. 

Conflicts of Interest
All authors report no conflicts of interest.

Acknowledgments
We would like to thank Lydia Thorpe, the medical librarian from Ontario Tech University for peer-reviewing our search strategy.

attributes.title: Patient reported satisfaction with acne treatment: a systematic review
attributes.description:
Are there any patient reported measures (PROMs) on satisfaction with acne treatment?
If so, what is the quality of these PROMs as assessed with the COSMIN methodology?

summary.value:
Acne vulgaris is a common chronic skin disease involving blockage and/or inflammation of pilosebaceous units (hair follicles and their accompanying sebaceous glands). Acne can present as clinically noninflammatory open and/or closed comedones (blackheads and whiteheads), inflammatory lesions (papules, pustules, cysts or nodules), or a mixture of both, affecting mostly the face but also the back and chest. A wide variety of topical and systemic treatments as well as procedural treatments are available. Acne can affect social and emotional wellbeing and can have a great impact on quality of life.
Outcome measures to assess the efficacy of acne treatments are heterogeneous and inconsistently applied. Recently seven core outcome domains have been identified that together form an Acne Core Outcome Set (ACORN project). We aim to identify and assess the quality of existing measures regarding one of these domains: satisfaction with treatment received.
We have attached our protocol for preregistration

attributes.title: Out-group bias and Performance Attribution for COVID-19 Response
attributes.description: This study examines factors that influence the way members of the public attribution blame or credit for the government's response to the spread of the COVID-19 virus in the United States. We look at two factors in particular: 1) equivalence framing, and 2) the name used to describe the virus (COVID - 19 versus the Chinese Virus).

q1.value: Gregory Porumbescu, Donald Moynihan, Jason Anastasopoulos, Asmus Leth Olsen

q2.value:
All hypotheses are directional. 

H1: Participants exposed to negatively framed performance data will be more negative in their assessments of the problem (extremely serious) and more negative in their evaluations of actors in the United States Federal Government than participants exposed to positively framed performance data.

H2: Participants exposed to the term 'Chinese Virus' will be more inclined to blame East Asian residents and the Chinese government when compared to participants exposed to the term 'COVID - 19.'

H3: Participants exposed to the term 'Chinese Virus' and negatively framed performance data will attribute greater blame for the response to the pandemic to East Asian and Chinese residents/Chinese government than participants exposed to the term 'COVID - 19' and negatively framed performance data.

H4: Participants exposed to the term 'Chinese Virus' and negatively framed performance data are less likely to blame the United States Federal Government for the spread of the pandemic than participants exposed to the term 'COVID - 19' and negatively framed performance data.


H5: Conservatives/Republicans will be more likely to understate the severity of the problem and blame actors other than the US Federal Government (non-governmental actors, other governments) 

H6: Liberals/Democrats will be more likely to view the problem as serious and blame actors in the US Federal Government more than other actors.

H7: The effect of positively framed performance data on support for actors in the US Federal Government will be greatest for Conservatives/Republicans.

H8: The effect of negatively framed performance data on blaming actors in the US Federal Government will be greatest for Liberals/Democrats

H9: The effect of the “Chinese virus” treatment on blaming East Asians/Chinese government will be greatest for Conservatives/Republicans.

H10: The effect of the “Chinese virus” treatment on blaming actors outside of the US Federal Government will be greatest for Conservatives/Republicans.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: This is a between subjects 2 (Chinese Virus vs. COVID - 19) X2 (positively framed performance data versus negatively framed performance data) factorial design where we randomly assign assignment to one of four treatment groups or two baseline conditions.

q7.value: Individual participants will be randomly assigned to one of 6 groups. The random number generator is supplied by the survey software.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
We will recruit White residents of the United States from Mechanical Turk using the TurkPrime
platform. Sampling criteria include approval ratings (greater than 85%) and number of hits (greater than 500). We will compensate participants between $0.75 and $1.00 depending upon how quickly our sample is filling and the estimated time to completion. The goal is to compensate participants at a rate that is roughly $10 per hour.

q11.value: We aim to have a usable sample of between 2000 and 3000 participants depending on the cost per participant and the speed with which the sample fills.

q12.value: We conducted a power analysis using the easypower package in R. Our desired power was 80%, significance level 0.05, and the effect size we aim to detect 0.01 (Cohen's F squared). The results of this analysis suggest 196 participants per group, meaning 1200 total participants. To ensure we meet this goal, we will oversample in the expectation that not all of the responses will be usable.

question.value: Manipulated variables include the way the COVID-19 is referred to -- either as the Chinese Virus or COVID-19 the way performance in responding to the pandemic is framed (negative framing versus positive framing)

We will rely on a mixture of open ended and close ended measures to evaluate the range of government and non government actors participants attribute responsibility to and how they evaluate performance of different actors. 

The wording for all items used to measure attribution and performance evaluations are included in the attached document.

We plan to use ANOVA (including planned contrasts), Bayesian equivalence testing, OLS regression to test for differences between groups. We will use structural topic models, sentiment analysis, and regularized logistic regression to analyze the open ended item.

q19.value: We will use the standard P<.05 criteria for evaluating results of the ANOVA and OLS analyses.

q20.value:
We will exclude all participants who completed the study in less than 180 seconds, responses coming from duplicate IP addresses. We include a number of open ended responses, which can be used to understand how much attention a participant has paid. We also include two manipulation checks at the end of the study:

1) What was the name of the federal agency you just read about?

2) How did the prompt you read refer to the virus? Please do your best to remember. 

However, we will present results including all participants (participants who passed and failed the manipulation checks) as well as a subsample of only those who passed.

attributes.title: Strength training exercise descriptors in rehabilitation after anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction: Protocol for Scoping Review
attributes.description: The primary outcome of this scoping review will be to investigated ACL reconstruction rehabilitation-both home-based, gym-based, and clinic-based interventions, considering the strength training section within the intervention for data extraction purposes and further analysis. A secondary aim will be to compare the ACLR programme literature to the current standard of reporting strength training exercise descriptors.

q1.value: Arnold Vlok, Derick Coetzee, Dr Nicol van Dyk, Hege Grindem

q2.value:
1. Which strength training exercise descriptors are used in rehabilitation after anterior
cruciate ligament reconstruction?
2. How does the literature compare to international standards of reporting strength training exercise descriptors?

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
The research team has decided to use a scoping review with the methodological framework, as proposed by (Arksey and Malley, 2005), as the primary outline for this protocol. Guidelines from the Joanna Briggs Institute informed the study design. The scoping review will follow a five stage framework, as described by Arksey and O’Malley (2005).
Stage 1: Identify the research question by connecting the purpose and research question.
Stage 2: Identify relevant studies by balancing feasibility with breadth and
comprehensiveness.
Stage 3: Implement an iterative study selection process by using a team approach to study selection and data extraction.
Stage 4: Charting the data, incorporating numerical summary and express data through
tables and graphs.
Stage 5: Collating, summarizing, and reporting the results, including the implication for clinical practice and research.

question.value:
The search strategy will include electronic bibliographic databases supplemented by additional strategies to identify published and unpublished evidence applicable to the question. The electronic databases MEDLINE, Academic Search Complete, Pubmed, SPORTDiscus and CINAHL will be searched from January 1990 up to September 2019. The Boolean phrase (ACLR or acl or "anterior cruciate ligament*") and (surgery or surgical or reconstruct*) and (exercis* or train* or progress* or therap*) n5 (strength* or resistance* or weight*) and (interven* or program* or protocol*) will be used as keyword phrase to search the different databases. The Cochrane Library of Systematic Reviews and the Clinical Trials Registry will be searched, applying the use of the same Boolean phrase. A manual search will be done from reference lists, using keywords derived from the Boolean phrase to expand the search in appropriate peer reviewed scientific journals.
Study selection process
Search results will be imported into an adjunct screening tool, an excel spreadsheet developed by a professional librarian VonVille, 2018. This spreadsheet (Supplementary Files\Projectname- PRIMARY-Excel-workbook.xlsx) will be reviewed by the research team to confirmed the reliability.

Level 1 Screening: Title and Abstract
Two independent screeners (AV and DC) will start level 1 initial screening process of each article. Conducting one training session before commencing the screening process will ensure the reliability of the screening between reviewers. The reviewers will independently complete a title and abstract relevance screening. Reviewers will compare and summarize the results within the customized excel spreadsheet workbook. Reasons for excluding will be reported.

Level 2 Screening: Full text
The remaining studies will be screened in full-text to determine eligibility. Reasons for
excluding will be provided. Any discrepancies between the reviewers will be resolved during a consensus meeting, or with a third reviewer if needed.

Data items and data collection process
Based on the PRISMA Extension for Scoping Reviews (PRISMA-ScR) guidelines, data
collection will be done by the researcher following a systematic approach. Data extraction will be performed independently by two reviewers.
A third reviewer will be called in to resolve conflicts in case of disagreement. An excel
spreadsheet template, specifically customized for this study, will be used for data extraction. The information recorded will be confirmed by the rest of the research team, who will check it jointly for mistakes after completion of the process. Two reviewers will independently extract data.

Inclusion Criteria
-Studies published between January 1990 and September 2019. Limiting the review to recent
studies will give the best reflection on current clinical practice.
-Studies on patients with ACLR in isolation or in combination with meniscus repair/resection,
or cartilage surgery.
-Studies of one or both sexes where participants are a minimum age of 16 years.
-Studies where the orthopaedic surgeon used either patella tendon or hamstring tendon
autografts for reconstruction.
-Level 1-4 studies published in the English language.
-Studies that describe strength training exercises as one of the rehabilitation modalities after
ACLR. Strength training exercises are defined as exercises that use a fixed mass as the
means of resistance (such as ankle-weights, plate-loaded resistance training machines or
free- weights).
-Studies that report at least one exercise descriptor for strength training in the post-operative
ACLR rehabilitation programme within the 2-12 months rehabilitation period.
-Studies where the rehabilitation programmes are either home-based, gym-based, or clinic-based

Exclusion Criteria
-Conference abstracts, opinion pieces, magazines and newspaper articles.
-Studies that include participants with ACL allografts, ACL repair, nonsurgically treated ACL
injuries, posterior cruciate ligament reconstruction and significant concomitant injuries to other
body parts.
-Studies that describe strength training only in combination with supplementary modalities
such as neuromuscular electric stimulation, blood flow restriction training or cryotherapy.

registration_responses.q6.question:
The research team has decided to use a scoping review with the methodological framework, as proposed by (Arksey and Malley, 2005), as the primary outline for this protocol. Guidelines from the Joanna Briggs Institute informed the study design. The scoping review will follow a five stage framework, as described by Arksey and O’Malley (2005).
Stage 1: Identify the research question by connecting the purpose and research question.
Stage 2: Identify relevant studies by balancing feasibility with breadth and
comprehensiveness.
Stage 3: Implement an iterative study selection process by using a team approach to study selection and data extraction.
Stage 4: Charting the data, incorporating numerical summary and express data through
tables and graphs.
Stage 5: Collating, summarizing, and reporting the results, including the implication for clinical practice and research.

The search strategy will include electronic bibliographic databases supplemented by additional strategies to identify published and unpublished evidence applicable to the question. The electronic databases MEDLINE, Academic Search Complete, Pubmed, SPORTDiscus and CINAHL will be searched from January 1990 up to September 2019. The Boolean phrase (ACLR or acl or "anterior cruciate ligament*") and (surgery or surgical or reconstruct*) and (exercis* or train* or progress* or therap*) n5 (strength* or resistance* or weight*) and (interven* or program* or protocol*) will be used as keyword phrase to search the different databases. The Cochrane Library of Systematic Reviews and the Clinical Trials Registry will be searched, applying the use of the same Boolean phrase. A manual search will be done from reference lists, using keywords derived from the Boolean phrase to expand the search in appropriate peer reviewed scientific journals.
Study selection process
Search results will be imported into an adjunct screening tool, an excel spreadsheet developed by a professional librarian VonVille, 2018. This spreadsheet (Supplementary Files\Projectname- PRIMARY-Excel-workbook.xlsx) will be reviewed by the research team to confirmed the reliability.

Level 1 Screening: Title and Abstract
Two independent screeners (AV and DC) will start level 1 initial screening process of each article. Conducting one training session before commencing the screening process will ensure the reliability of the screening between reviewers. The reviewers will independently complete a title and abstract relevance screening. Reviewers will compare and summarize the results within the customized excel spreadsheet workbook. Reasons for excluding will be reported.

Level 2 Screening: Full text
The remaining studies will be screened in full-text to determine eligibility. Reasons for
excluding will be provided. Any discrepancies between the reviewers will be resolved during a consensus meeting, or with a third reviewer if needed.

Data items and data collection process
Based on the PRISMA Extension for Scoping Reviews (PRISMA-ScR) guidelines, data
collection will be done by the researcher following a systematic approach. Data extraction will be performed independently by two reviewers.
A third reviewer will be called in to resolve conflicts in case of disagreement. An excel
spreadsheet template, specifically customized for this study, will be used for data extraction. The information recorded will be confirmed by the rest of the research team, who will check it jointly for mistakes after completion of the process. Two reviewers will independently extract data.

Inclusion Criteria
-Studies published between January 1990 and September 2019. Limiting the review to recent
studies will give the best reflection on current clinical practice.
-Studies on patients with ACLR in isolation or in combination with meniscus repair/resection,
or cartilage surgery.
-Studies of one or both sexes where participants are a minimum age of 16 years.
-Studies where the orthopaedic surgeon used either patella tendon or hamstring tendon
autografts for reconstruction.
-Level 1-4 studies published in the English language.
-Studies that describe strength training exercises as one of the rehabilitation modalities after
ACLR. Strength training exercises are defined as exercises that use a fixed mass as the
means of resistance (such as ankle-weights, plate-loaded resistance training machines or
free- weights).
-Studies that report at least one exercise descriptor for strength training in the post-operative
ACLR rehabilitation programme within the 2-12 months rehabilitation period.
-Studies where the rehabilitation programmes are either home-based, gym-based, or clinic-based

Exclusion Criteria
-Conference abstracts, opinion pieces, magazines and newspaper articles.
-Studies that include participants with ACL allografts, ACL repair, nonsurgically treated ACL
injuries, posterior cruciate ligament reconstruction and significant concomitant injuries to other
body parts.
-Studies that describe strength training only in combination with supplementary modalities
such as neuromuscular electric stimulation, blood flow restriction training or cryotherapy.

attributes.title: Reducing Prejudice through Self-Affirmation
attributes.description: Research suggests that self-affirmation can reduce threat in a multitude of domains (e.g., stereotype threat). Given the capacity for self-affirmation to reduce threats to the self of various types, the current work examines the capacity for self-affirmation to reduce outgroup prejudice, and the mechanisms which explain this effect.

q2.value:
Participants engaged in self-affirmation will report lower levels of outgroup prejudice as compared to a control condition (Hypothesis I). 

Intergroup anxiety will mediate the relationship between self-affirmation and prejudice: those in the self-affirmation condition will show lower levels of intergroup anxiety as compared to those in the control condition, and higher levels of intergroup anxiety will be associated with higher levels of outgroup prejudice (Hypothesis II).

Self-compassion will mediate the effect of self-affirmation on prejudice. Specifically, those in the self-affirmation condition will show higher levels of self-compassion as compared to those in the control condition; in addition, higher levels of self-compassion will be associated with lower levels of outgroup prejudice (Hypothesis III).

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: The study will use a between-subjects design. Participants will be randomly assigned to either a self-affirmation or control condition. Participants will also be asked to answer questions measuring the mediating variables (intergroup anxiety and self-compassion). In addition, participants will be assessed for attitudes toward Elderly people. Upon completion of the study, participants will be debriefed, thanked, and compensated online.

q7.value: Block randomization will be used, set up using the Randomizer in Qualtrics survey flow. An embedded data item (condition) will be entered to assign participants to the self-affirmation or control condition.

q12.value:
A power analysis using G*Power  determined that a sample size of N = 328 participants would be needed to obtain power of .95 to detect a small effect of .20, to examine differences between two groups. 

We disclose that because of COVID-19 disrupting the lives of students (the sample) and researchers, our data collection  may be lower than our proposed 450 participants.

We therefore may have to end data collection upon the end of the semester, or if the number of credits participants are required to obtain are reduced, which would reduce the number of subjects that register for the study.

question.value:
The study will use a between-subjects design. Participants will be randomly assigned to either a self-affirmation or control condition. Following the same procedure adopted in other studies (e.g., Badea, Bender, & Korda, 2020), all participants will be given a list of values (listed below) and will rank-order the values from most to least importance to them. Those in the self-affirmation condition will write about the value they identified as most important; those in the control condition will write about the value least important to them. 

The self-affirmation values and domains include: artistic skill, athletics, business/money, creativity, independence, music, relationships, religious values, sense of humor, politics, and spontaneity

Outgroup attitudes. Participants will be asked to provide their attitudes toward Elderly people. Following Amiot and Hornsey (2010), participants will first be given feeling thermometers (e.g., 0 to 100, cold/warm, unfriendly/friendly, distant/close, different/similar) and asked to indicate the amount of warmth they feel toward Elderly people. Then, participants will be provided with a series of adjectives (i.e., intelligent, friendly, likeable, immature, cultivated, boring, talented, sympathetic, stubborn, trustworthy, bad, dishonest, truthful) and asked to indicate how they believe Elderly people rank on each adjective (i.e., 1 = not at all; 9 = extremely). Negative adjectives will be reverse-coded, meaning that higher scores will indicate more positive ratings for Elderly people. The feeling thermometers and adjectives will be standardized and combined to form a single index of attitudes toward Elderly people. To mask the interest in collecting responses toward Elderly people, participants will make feeling thermometer ratings toward other age categories (Middle-aged people, Young adults, & children). Participants will also rate Middle-aged people & Young adults on the adjectives ratings. 

Intergroup anxiety. The Intergroup Anxiety scale (Stephan & Stephan, 1985) will measure negative emotions toward interacting with a group of Elderly people (i.e., 0 = not at all, 9 = extremely). Participants will be asked to indicate the extent to which they feel each of six negative items (e.g., uncertain, worried, awkward, anxious, threatened, and nervous) and six positive items (e.g., comfortable, trusting, friendly, confident, safe, and at ease). Positive items will be reverse-coded, and items will be combined to form a measure of intergroup anxiety. 

Self-compassion. Self-compassion will be measured using the 12-item Self-Compassion Scale-Short Form (Raes, Pommier, Neff, & Van Gucht, 2011). An example item includes: “I try to see my failings as part of the human condition” and the scale is measured using a 5-point Likert scale (1 = Almost never, 5 = Almost always).

Additional demographics will also be collected (see Study 3 Qualtrics Measures)

First, in a regression analysis, condition (1 = self-affirmation; 0 = control) will be examined as a predictor of outgroup prejudice. Then, to test the theoretical model depicted in Figure 1, the PROCESS macro (Version 3; Hayes, 2013) will be used to determine the parallel mediational influences of intergroup anxiety and self-compassion on outgroup prejudice.

q20.value: Participants will be excluded from analyses if they 1) answer zero of three attention checks correctly, 2) fail to answer one of the three manipulation checks correctly, 3) are identified as an outliers (defined as ±2.5 standard deviations above or below the mean of the outcome variable in a given analysis), or 5) if the IP address or pawprint/student ID number repeats with an additional participant in the dataset.

q21.value: Participants that fail to provide data on the self-affirmation manipulation, measures of prejudice, or measures of self-compassion or intergroup anxiety, will not be analyzed.

q22.value: Potential covariates (e.g., religious affiliation, gender, political orientation) may be explored for their influences on these relationships. For example, it could be speculated that attitudes toward the elderly may be influenced by demographics variables.

Our department is considering reducing the required number of research credits students have to obtain in Psych 1000 this Spring 2020 semester. 

We are intending to post timeslots for 450 participants for our online study. However, our data collection may be less than 450, because of the challenges students are facing because of COVID-19. We disclose our intention to collect 450 participants while recognizing that our data collection may not reach 450 because of the challenges this sample is currently facing.

attributes.title: Efficacy and safety of heat-sensitive moxibustion therapy for allergic rhinitis: protocol for a systematic review and meta analysis
attributes.description: Allergic rhinitis (AR) is a common symptomatic, inflammatory and immunological disorder of nasal mucosa results from allergen exposure triggered IgE response. Epidemiology of allergic rhinitis varies according to different factors like genetic constitution, racial differences, socio-economic conditions, chances of exposure to different allergens, sex, growth stages. AR shows high prevalence among developed countries. AR is managed with first and second anti histamines (56%), intra nasal corticosteroids (25%) and mast cell stabilizers (19%). Prolonged usage of these medications is necessary in beating the disease as far as the recurrence is concerned. This may lead to numerous serious health hazards. Studies have shown that negative effects of sedative anti-histamines last to the succeeding day disturbing the day time performance. Traditional Chinese medicine in the treatment of allergic rhinitis has done a lot of research, the effect is significant. There are no SR or protocol on heat-sensitive moxibustion therapy for allergic rhinitis. Therefore, research on it is needed.

q1.value: Qinxiu Zhang, Deyun Wang, Lei Cheng, Yan Ruan, Peng Liu, Kexin Hu, Xuanpu Gong, Jinhui Liu, Rongchang Feng, Jianying Gao, Hui Xie, Xinrong Li, Qinwei Fu

q2.value:
1. Heat-sensitive moxibustion therapy is effective for treatment of patients with allergic rhinitis.
2. How does the efficacy of heat-sensitive moxibustion therapy compare to that with normal moxibustion therapy, Western medicine therapies alone, other TCM therapies alone, blank control, placebo control and other interventions? 
3. There are some moderating variables associated with treatment efficacy in studies of heat-sensitive moxibustion therapy for patients with the allergic rhinitis.

q3.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: Personnel who analyze the data collected from the study are not aware of the treatment applied to any given group.

q5.value:
Three reviewers searched the online databases listed above and recorded the titles and abstracts of all the articles.
Three evaluators assessed the eligibility of these articles and made decisions on every research (inclusion or exclusion) independently. If they did not reach the same decision, the concerned articles were discussed with a fourth reviewer.
Three reviewers extracted data independently from each study.
Differences regarding the extracted data were resolved after discussion with a fourth reviewer.
Three authors of our review team will independently assess the methodological quality of included trials, and consensus will be reached by discussion with a third party in case of discrepancy.

The methodological quality of RCTs will be assessed according to the risk of bias tool described in the Cochrane Handbook for Systematic Reviews of Interventions [Higgins JPT 2009]. Six elements will be assessed: random sequence generation, allocation concealment, blinding of outcome assessors, incomplete outcome data, free of selective reporting, and other bias. Disagreements will be resolved by discussion with a third party.

question.value:
1. Anticipated start date: 08/04/2020;

2. Anticipated completion date: 05/06/2020;

3.Review question: ①. 1. Is heat-sensitive moxibustion therapy an effective treatment for patiens with allergic rhinitis?
                                  ②. How does the efficacy of heat-sensitive moxibustion therapy compare to that with normal moxibustion, acupuncture, having western medicines, blank control, placebo control and other interventions?
                                  ③. What moderating variables are associated with treatment effectiveness in studies of heat-sensitive moxibustion therapy for patients with allergic rhinitis? 

4. Searches: English databases including PubMed, Embase, Cochrane Library and Chinese databases including CNKI, Wanfang, VIP databases will be searched. The research will start following the PRISMA protocol.
The terms used in the search will follow the rules of the Medical Subject Headings (MeSH) and the question that guided the search was based on the PICOS strategy (participants, interventions, comparison, results and studies). search strategy information can be found in the attached PDF document (link provided below).
One week will be allocated for data collection and one week for article analysis.
Retrieval time is from the inception dates of the databases to 20 Apri, 2020.
We also considered the alternative terms and spellings for keywords.
In addition, the references of initially included literature were traced back to achieve a comprehensive search. English and Chinese language were included.

5. Condition or domain being studied: Allergic rhinitis (AR) is a common symptomatic, inflammatory and immunological disorder of nasal mucosa results from allergen exposure triggered IgE response. Epidemiology of allergic rhinitis varies according to different factors like genetic constitution, racial differences, socio-economic conditions, chances of exposure to different allergens, sex, growth stages. AR shows high prevalence among developed countries. AR is managed with first and second anti histamines (56%), intra nasal corticosteroids (25%) and mast cell stabilizers (19%). Prolonged usage of these medications is necessary in beating the disease as far as the recurrence is concerned. This may lead to numerous serious health hazards. Studies have shown that negative effects of sedative anti-histamines last to the succeeding day disturbing the day time performance. Traditional Chinese medicine in the treatment of allergic rhinitis has done a lot of research, the effect is significant. There are no SR or protocol on heat-sensitive moxibustion therapy for allergic rhinitis. Therefore, research on it is needed.

6.Participants/population: Participants with all types of allergic rhinitis (including intermittent allergic rhinitis and persistent allergic rhinitis) regardless of gender, age, etiology, ethnic group, severity, diagnosed with specific criteria (i.e. mention any one of criteria for diagnosis of allergic rhinitis) are eligible for inclusion. Complicated with asthma, nasosinusitis are excluded.

7. Intervention(s), exposure(s): Treatment of heat-sensitive moxibustion therapy.

8. Comparator(s)/control: Including normal moxibustion, acupuncture, western medicines, blank control, placebo control and other interventions. Interventions in the experimental group were not included.

9. Types of study to be included: We will include randomised controlled trials (RCTs), published and unpublished, in English and Chinese.

10. Main outcome(s): ①Total Nasal Symptom Score (TNSS) and four key symptoms' scores;
                                      ②Rhinitis Quality of Life Questionnaire (RQLQ); 
                                      ③VAS score;
                                      ④Total effective rate;
                                      ⑤Score for signs and symptoms;
                                      ⑥The improvement of disease classification.

11. Additional outcome(s): ① TNNSS;
                                                ②Laboratory index, eg. IgE, IL;
                                                ③Recurrence rate;
                                                ④Time when the symptoms disappear;
                                                ⑤Frequency of seizure;
                                                ⑥The case of drug reduction.

12. Data extraction (selection and coding): Three reviewers searched the online databases listed above and recorded the titles and abstracts of all the articles.
Three evaluators assessed the eligibility of these articles and made decisions on every research (inclusion or exclusion) independently. If they did not reach the same decision, the concerned articles were discussed with a fourth reviewer.
Three reviewers extracted data independently from each study.
Differences regarding the extracted data were resolved after discussion with a fourth reviewer.

Studies have shown that negative effects of sedative anti-histamines last to the succeeding day disturbing the day time performance. Traditional Chinese medicine in the treatment of allergic rhinitis has done a lot of research, the effect is significant. There are no SR or protocol on heat-sensitive moxibustion therapy for allergic rhinitis. Therefore, research on it is needed.

q2.value: Emilia Lubowietzki, Eva Walter, Richard Künzel, Isabel Escherlor , Lena Rohleder, Maike Borchardt, Maxine Uhlmann, Kira Eckert, Anna-Lena Lünert, David Schackmann, Sophie Hauswald, Roman Sachse, Philine Bleihöfer, Helena Rabe, Fabienne Andrees, Elena Hüttermann, Kornelius Schmidt, Nathania Seanette Rochelle, Jan Husmann, Lydia Richter, Luisa Matticzk, Juliane Lucas, Viktoria-Loreen Mahncke, Svenja Oestreicher, Til Herrmann, Miriam-Sophie Petasch

q3.value: In order to replicate the study by Williams & Bargh („Experiencing Physical Warmth Promotes Interpersonal Warmth“) we will investigate whether the tactile experience of physical warmth has an influence on our judgement concerning the concept of interpersonal warmth. In the original study participants judged a target individual to have a warmer personality when they briefly held a cup of hot coffee before compared to those who held a cup of iced coffee.

q4.value:
Our aim is to replicate the findings of the original study (Experiment 1).

I.	Experiencing physical warmth  activates concepts of interpersonal warmth which therefore makes participants perceive other people as being warmer. 
II.	The activation of interpersonal warmth concepts influences judgments of other people without one being aware of it.
III.	There is no significant difference between male and female participants.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

q7.value: In contrast to original study, confederates know hypotheses (no blinding).

question.value: We have a between-subject design with one factor (temperature) with two levels (hot vs. cold coffee)

q9.value: It will be randomized whether the individual participant gets to hold a hot or cold coffee. For randomization we will use SPSS code that will randomly assign the participants to one of the two conditions.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Our participants will all be 3rd semester Psychology students form the Technische Universität Dresden, Germany. As this replication is done as a part of the so called “Experimentalpsychologisches Arbeiten“ (ExPra), an obligatory course for all Psychology students at the Technische Universität Dresden, we will be bound to some limitations. All our participants will be assigned to our study and obligated to take part in it in order to pass the course.  

Like the original study we will use a cover story where the participants are told that our study is investigating the relationship between person perception and consumerism. Therefore, they will be asked to fill out two questionnaires.

At the end they will be asked several questions to figure out to which extent they were aware of the influence of the hot/cold coffee and our hypotheses (debriefing).

q13.value: To allow for a valid replication our sample size will range from at least 41 (original study) to 52 participants at most (due to ExPra rules).

q14.value: We used the software program GPower to conduct a power analysis. As a result, we obtain a power of 0.8 (Cohen, J. (1988). Statistical power analysis for the behavioral sciences (2nd ed.). Hillsdale, NJ: Lawrence Erlbaum) to detect a (medium) effect size of 0.28 (No evidence that experiencing physical warmth promotes interpersonal warmth: Two failures to replicate Williams and Bargh (2008))  at the standard .05 alpha error probability.

question.value:
We manipulated the temperature of the coffee (independent variable):
-      hot coffee vs. cold coffee (two levels)

We use ordinary instant coffee.
To make cold coffee, we make coffee at the beginning of the day of the experiment and then store it in the refrigerator. 
For the warm condition we use boiling water to brew a cup of instant coffee and let it cool down for approximately 10 minutes before the arrival of the participant.

Our main variable of measurement will be the participants’ perception of the warmth of the people described depending on whether the participant held a hot or cold coffee before. We operationalize participants’ perception of warmth and cold of people through the “Personality Impression Questionnaire” with a 10 - point - scale [1 = cold, 10 = warm], only using the scale “Interpersonal Warmth” (not the scale “unrelated”). Five of ten items are related to human perception of warm and cold dimension, whereas the other five of ten items are unrelated to warm and cold dimension. 

Covariates: In addition, we will measure the gender and age of the participants , the extent to which the smell and taste of coffee is liked and their current mood before and after the questionnaires.

Items related to warm and cold dimension will be combined into one indice called “Interpersonal Warmth” as dependent variable. 
The other items unrelated to warm and cold dimension will be combined to another indice “unrelated”.

- t-Test for independent samples 
- To analyze gender, we will use ANOVA

q21.value: P-values smaller than alpha levels of .05 are considered to be significant.

q22.value: We will not exclude participants due to our limited sample size. This also applies to the criterion of native language, since it is not possible to exclude someone from the ExPra if their native language is not German.

q23.value:
If data are missing because participants dropped out during the session, all data of these participants will be discarded and excluded from analysis. Data from missing subjects will be replaced by data from new participants in the same condition

If data are missing because participants dropped out during the session, we will use statistical average data to replace the missing data using imputation. We will not exclude data fully from participants who do not fill in all answers of the questionnaire.

q24.value: We want to take a look at the influence of coffee preference on perception of interpersonal warmth.

q25.value: Participants might know hypotheses because of studying this empirical study in another course. This will be analyzed through a debriefing technique. We will not exclude data of these participants because of our limited sample size.

attributes.title: Entspannungstechniken im Studium
attributes.description: Auswirkungen von Übungen auf das Rsisikoverhalten

q2.value: Nikita Leimann, Amanda Stadtmann, Tamara Meier, Marina Haller

q4.value: 1. Probanden ,welche extensive Übungen ausführen und eine Power Pose einnehmen, werden  im Fragebogen zur Risikobereitschaft einen höheren Risiko-Wert erlangen und im Risikospiel risikofreudiger spielen, als die Versuchspersonen, welche die submissiven Übungen durchführen und submissiven Haltungen einnehmen.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
between subject design.   
eine unabhängigen Variable(Übung/Haltung) mit zwei Ausprägungen(extensive/high-power Übungen, submissive/low-power Übungen)
abhängige Variable(Risikospiel und Aiss-d)

q9.value: Wir werden apriori die Experimentalgruppen anhand der Extraversionswerte bilden, sodass die Mittelwerte unter den Gruppen eine geringere Varianz aufweisen.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Teilnehmer werden in diversen studentischen Online Plattformen (OLAT und Mail) oder durch social media rekrutiert. 
Die Teilnahmebedingungen sind: 18-25 Jahre alt, keine körperlichen Beinträchtigungen, Deutsch als Muttersprache(oder sehr gute Deutschkenntnisse), internetzugang.  
Die Versuchsteilnehmer werden für die Teilnahme (ca. 30 min) mit einer halben Versuchspersonenstunde entlöhnt.

q13.value:
Unsere Stichprobengrösse beläuft sich auf midestens 134 Personen für die logitische Regression. Dabei befinden sich 67 pro Gruppe. 
Für die ANCOVA beläuft sich die Stichprobengrösse auf 63. Für unser Experiment wählen wir 64 Personen, weil wir 2 gleich grosse Gruppen brauchen (32/32). 
Wir versuchen 134 Versuchspersoinen zu rekrutieren.

q14.value:
Wir nutzten das Programm G-Power, um unsere Stichprobengrösse zu berechnen. Für die Ancova ist es unser Ziel eine mittlere Effektstärke von .4 , eine Power von .8, bei einem standadisierten Alphafehler von .025, zu erreichen. 
Zusätzlich nutzten wir für die logistische Regression das Programm G-Power. Dabei ist unser Ziel eine Power von .8, einen R2 von .25,  bei einem standadiesierten Alphafehler von .0025, einer Odds Ratio von 6.71 und PR 0.5, zu erreichen.

question.value: Wir manipulieren die Übungen (exzessive / submissive Übungen) der Versuchspersonen.

zur Messung der Extraversion benutzen wir den Big Five Inventar 2 (BFI-2) deutsche Version. Wir benötigen  aus den 60 Items die 12 Items zur Extraversion. 5 stufige Skala von 1.Stimme überhaupt nicht zu bis 5.  Stimme voll und ganz zu. 
Zur Messung der Kovariate Gewissenhaftigkeit brauchen wir die 12 Items aus dem BFI-2 deutsche Version.5 stufige Skala von 1.Stimme überhaupt nicht zu bis 5.  Stimme voll und ganz zu. 
Zur Messung der Risikobereitschaft benutzen wir den Arnett Inventory of Sensation Seeking- deutsche Version(Roth & Mayerhofer (2014). Diese besteht aus 20 Items, mit einer 4 stufigen Likert-Skala(von 1. Trifft gar nicht auf mich zu bis 4. Trifft stark auf mich zu).   
Zusätzlich führen wir ein Risikospiel (A. Holt & K. Laury) zur Erfassung der Risikobereitschaft durch. In dem Spiel muss man sich in 10 Entscheidungen zwischen Alternative A und B entscheiden. In den 10 Entscheidungen sind die Gewinnchancen für den Geldbetrag unterschiedlich. ( 1) Alternative A. mit 10% Gewinn von 2,00 CHF mit 90% Gewinn von 1,60 CHF oder Alternative B. mit 10% Gewinn von 3,85 CHF mit 90% Gewinn von 0,10 CHF bis zu 10. Alternative A. mit 100% Gewinn von 2,00 CHF mit 0% Gewinn von 1,60 CHF oder Alternative B. mit 100% Gewinn von 3,85 CHF mit 0% Gewinn von 0,10 CHF). Der hypothetische Geldbetrag wird um den Faktor 20, 50 und 90 multipliziert (4 Spiele)

Wir nutzen die Kovarianzanalyse(ANCOVA) mit den Gruppen(extensiv/submissiv) als Faktor und Gewissenhaftigkeit als Kovariate, die abhängige Variable ist das intervallskalierte Antwortverhalten im AISS-d.
Zudem nutzen wir die multiple logistische Regression mit den Gruppen(extensiv/submissiv) als Faktor und Gewissenhaftigkeit als Kovariate, die abhängige Variable ist das Antwortverhalten(10 bivariate Entscheidungen) im Risikospiel.

q20.value: Wir transformieren den ordinalskalierten AISS-d Fragebogen in intervallskaliertes Niveau um.
